7.12.18  8:32 am   did you know your website works really well using free and open source text-based, terminal browser technology? that's actually pretty rare. for people who like to deal with files and music directly (because youtube can sometimes seem a little bit evil) have you ever considered a mailing list or similar to announce your music? they're not very hard to set up! and i think they would increase your cred and fame in certain communities.

7.11.18  2:06 pm   i don't really get 'negative harmony'!

     
in the key of C the V chord is G.
by the powers of negative harmony G7 becomes Fm6..
so its a minor plagal cadence. i get that and i use it often because i really like the sound of it.
here is where i get confused though:
how does Fm6 actually derive from G7?
and would (if the same techniques applied) every other chord from the keycenter also have a 'negative' version??

7.11.18  1:28 pm   just wanted to say that the chord progression in 'hello sexy pants' that takes place starting with 'every day is such a lovely day to wake up in the morning' through 'at the grocery store, some one will tell you that what changed was you' is maybe one of the most pleasing things that my ears have ever heard. what kind of thought process goes into crafting things like this for you?

     is there a lot of revision that goes into it, or do you pretty much know what you want it to sound like for the most part before hand?

7.11.18  12:18 am   How do you motivate yourself to practice your music?

     I'm learning guitar, and I genuinely care passionately about it. The only thing is that I don't practice as often as I should. I don't wanna practice around people because I'm afraid of screwing up, but at the same time, I'm increasing my potential of screwing up by not practicing. It's really frustrating.

7.10.18  10:20 pm   damn. i'm messing around with a chord progression, and right when i end it i can hear the next chord in the sequence and i know exactly what it needs to sound like. but i dont know what the actual notes in the chord are because i still kinda suck at recognizing more complex chords. any advice?
my last chord is A minor with a D# (i don't know the abbreviated chord name) and the chord it resolves to is lower and has a C in it somewhere. what would that normally resolve to, following harmonic trends?
